Global (Jordan, Liberia, Uganda, Zambia): Pandemic Preparedness and Response: Strengthening National Legal and Policy Frameworks to Address Public Health Emergencies, Including COVID-19

description.narrative: 1) To conduct a participatory gap analysis of the current national legal and policy frameworks in selected countries and develop a roadmap to legal and policy reforms needed to strengthen national pandemic preparedness and response. 2) Based on the findings of the participatory gap-analysis and roadmap, to support the development of technical assistance plans to define and guide IDLO’s technical support to countries. 3) To deliver technical assistance and provide preliminary capacity development support to government and non-governmental stakeholders to enhance the necessary legal and policy reforms.

The project aims to contribute to the ‘UN Framework for the immediate socio-economic response to COVID-19’, by supporting countries in strengthening national legal and policy frameworks on preparedness and responses to public health emergencies.

description.narrative: 1) To introduce online mediation for efficient resolving of commercial disputes during and post the COVID-19 period and make mediators a viable alternative to courts. 2) To strengthen capacity building of key players (such as mediators and judges) on online commercial mediation to encourage them to refer mediable disputes to mediation. 3) To involve the business community, in particular SMEs, by means of a targeted mediation awareness raising campaign and piloting mediation.

Direct beneficiaries: The Supreme Court of the Kyrgyz Republic (SC), the High Justice Training Centre (HJTC) under the SC, the Republican Community of Mediators of the Kyrgyz Republic (RCM) and Mediation Centers, Kyrgyz mediators and SMEs.

The project aims to assist the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic with promoting and facilitating the use of commercial mediation to small and medium enterprises (SMEs), specifically during and post the COVID-19 pandemic period, with the goal of making the use of mediation, including online mediation, a business norm in the Kyrgyz Republic.

title.narrative: Provision of Emergency Shelter and Camp Coordination and Camp Management Assistance for Populations Affected by the Northern Ethiopian Crisis and COVID-19-Related Health Services for Humanitarian Actors in Tigray

description.narrative: In Ethiopia, the internal displacement and humanitarian needs are mainly derived by the ongoing conflicts and floods in the country. The ongoing conflicts, climate shocks and displacements continue to pose serious protection concerns for the affected population. The majority of the displaced population live-in collective sites or in spontaneous settlements where they have limited access to essential services, dignified and safe living conditions and lack necessary resources to sustain their families and communities. The response under this proposed project includes three components camp coordination and camp management interventions targeting 12 internally displaced persons (IDP) sites; emergency shelter assistance targeting 72,000 IDPs; and COVID-19 related health services for staff from United Nations, Humanitarian International Non-Governmental Organizations, and national non-governmental organizations. Proposed interventions address urgent gaps and needs identified through multi-sector assessments in Tigray region, in particularly lack of emergency shelters, inadequate /missing coordination of IDP sites, and lacking COVID-19 testing for staff deployed to this emergency.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Fostering Local Communities of Solidarity for Migrants and Refugees from Venezuela

description.narrative: In response to the Venezuelan migrant and refugee crisis in the Latin American region, IOM, UNHCR and UNHabitat will support cities to strengthen their policies on the social and economic integration, working closely with migrants, refugees and host communities to promote social cohesion, equal access to services and the guarantee of human rights. This initiative will be looking at migration and refugee policies from a comprehensive local sustainable development perspective considering the consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic on migrants' and refugees' coping mechanisms and livelihoods, combining the mandates and experiences of three UN agencies. In addition, cities of implementation will be Barranquilla and Cucutá - Colombia, Lima - Peru, Quito - Ecuador, and Santo Domingo - Dominican Republic.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Progressing the Revival of Women Entrepreneurs for Strengthened Economic Empowerment in the Republic of the Marshall Islands

description.narrative: This project contributes to strengthening of economic empowerment in the Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI) through the continued revival of Women Entrepreneurs (WE), a members' network established in 2013 through “Women United Together Marshall Islands”. IOM will provide continued human resource, technical support and resources to the revival of the network, through secondment of a dedicated network staff as well as lead the implementation of the WE strategic plan. A number of new activities will also be rolled out including community outreach and network development on Ebeye and the outer islands, intensive business management training courses for all members, provision of laptop and internet access for members use at a co-working space, showcase events and the creation of an e-commerce platform for members. These activities will also support the enduring challenges faced by women to start or grow their business in the RMI under the threat of COVID-19.

title.narrative: Support for the Mobilization of Young People, Actors of Social Cohesion and Peace in the Center North and Sahel Regions of Burkina Faso

description.narrative: The project responds to the need to strengthen social cohesion between host communities and displaced populations of the Center North and Sahel regions in Burkina Faso. With the aim to carry out activities to help prevent or reduce existing tensions and to strengthen social cohesion between communities, through this project, IOM focuses on placing the public administration at the center of the process in a logic of national and local ownership. The initiative responds to youth problems by bringing together young people from different communities around joint micro-projects selected by the public administration and implemented by micro-grants delivered to youth. Effective communication around the good practices of such young incubators are intended to create multiplier effects at the local and national levels to build and consolidate peace and social cohesion between communities. The project also includes awareness raising and training activities on COVID-19 and other sensitization activities to prepare the population to prevent these risks and avoid potential reject from host communities that could exacerbate vulnerabilities.

title.narrative: UN Joint-Project to Address Cooking Fuel Needs, Environmental Degradation and Food Security for Populations Affected by the Refugee Crisis: Safe Access to Fuel and Energy (SAFE) Plus - SIDA

description.narrative: Through this project, IOM aim is to contribute to the overall food and nutrition security, empowerment and resilience of households in Cox’s Bazar (Bangladesh). To achieve this, the project has four objectives, the first of which is to address the urgent cooking fuel needs of the Rohingya and host communities by providing Liquid Petroleum Gas. The second objective focuses on livelihoods activities for host communities—strengthening social cohesion, livelihoods and income generation for the heavily impacted host community through training and input provision; the third objective aims to reduce negative environmental impacts through land/forest rehabilitation. The fourth objective aims at increasing income generation by increasing agricultural production and marketing. To adapt to COVID-19, this project is reprogramming through cash transfers to host community households and adjustments to procurement, distribution, and planting for rice and forestry activities.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Disaster Resilience in the Compact Nations (RESILIENCE)

description.narrative: This project aims at supporting to national and state task forces on developing and implementing risk communication and community engagement plans related to the COVID-19 response in the Federated States of Micronesia and Republic of the Marshall Islands. In the Federal States of Micronesia, this includes the provision of technical guidance, production and distribution of national outreach campaigns, and facilitating online trainings for health workers using WHO standards; support to points of entry (POE) activities, including the improvement of infrastructure, procurement of safety and communication equipment to improve surveillance, and facilitating online trainings on screening and managing travelers for border and immigration officers. In the Republic of the Marshall Islands, this project responds to the overall planning and coordination activities of government counterparts, including by providing technical and resource support to emergency operations centers and national response planning efforts; improving communication pathways through communication equipment, trainings, and expanded risk communication and community engagement; and supporting POE measures through the development of standard operating procedures, quality assurance and quality control mechanisms, monitoring and evaluation and reporting mechanisms, as well as hygiene and infrastructure improvements.

title.narrative: Assessing and Addressing the Impacts of COVID-19 on Societies, Economies and Vulnerable Groups in Countries of the Middle East and North Africa Region

description.narrative: To help mitigate the socio-economic impacts of COVID-19, IOM is implementing this regional project in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) with the aim to respond to the financial and socio-economic impact of disruptions of COVID-19 on migrant, displaced populations and host communities in the region. In particular, IOM is: (1) conducting research and providing technical support through cash-based interventions in early recovery and post crisis contexts in the region; (2) developing regional research products on the socio-economic impact of COVID-19 on different countries in the MENA region; and 3) improving the understanding of existing social protection schemes in the MENA region in terms of their accessibility for migrants and displaced populations, of particular concern being migrants and displaced populations in the informal economy.

title.narrative: Costa Rica: Local Recycling Knowledge Transfer in San Juan, Ciudad Quesada

description.narrative: The objective of this project is to foster social cohesion and integration for migrant populations through local knowledge sharing and economic empowerment related to recycling in the San Juan neighborhood of Quesada City (Costa Rica). Prevailing poverty, unemployment, an absence of law enforcement, widespread violence and crime, and the regular arrival of migrants to the area, have caused this neighborhood to near a potential crisis situation. This has been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, as it has created a socioeconomic downturn which is adversely affecting all of Costa Rican society, and a burden that is falling heaviest on migrants. The foundation of this project is based on initiatives already underway in San Juan to empower women in the community as drivers of economic and social development. IOM aims to expand the impact of the San Juan Recycling Center, a cooperative formed by Nicaraguan women, by introducing value added processes and encouraging the transfer of recycling knowledge.

title.narrative: Community Stabilization Through Returned Migrant Reintegration in Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan During and After COVID-19

description.narrative: Heavy socioeconomic impacts resulting from COVID-19 travel restrictions are pushing migrant families into poverty in Central Asia. Many migrants are already experiencing great stress associated with failed migration and increased competition for the jobs available. Large numbers of unemployed migrants having faced COVID-19 pressures, may negatively impact social cohesion, such as some turning to crime or exacerbating existing discontent amongst the cohort of returning migrants and the communities to which they return. Through this project, IOM aims to utilise a proven methodology for migrant engagement and reintegration planning to work with returned migrants in five localities of the Osh, Jalal-Abad and Batken regions of Kyrgyzstan and targeted communities of the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Oblast of Tajikistan. In addition, IOM engages with community structures to build social cohesion and provide targeted assistance and support to cases displaying high vulnerability to poverty, crime, or conflict.

title.narrative: Police Professionalization and Community Policing in the Democratic Republic of the Congo - Phase IV

description.narrative: The goal of Phase IV of this project is to contribute to the improvement of security governance and the rule of law in Lubumbashi, Mbuji Mayi, Goma and Bukavu In the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) by supporting security sector reform and police professionalization. In light of the evolving security and public health context in the DRC, the project seeks to implement the remaining training activities of the previous phase in addition to expanding the community policing approach and using it to strengthen the police's COVID-19 response. As such the project will focus on; capacity development of security actors, including police services, civilian authorities, and community members; strengthening of good security governance and the rule of law according to the community policing system and principles; and support to security actors involved in the enforcement of the COVID-19 response plan including any restrictions taken by the Government.

description.narrative: Through this project, IOM supports governments in the Republic of Colombia, the Republic of Ecuador and the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in their COVID-19 responses to foster resilience, promote integration by improving the health response, community engagement and environmental protection of affected communities. Prevention of the Transmission of COVID-19 and the Reduction of the Community Tensions Linked to COVID-19 in High Risk Border Areas of the Central African Republic

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to help prevent the local transmission of COVID-19 by raising awareness among populations particularly exposed in the border areas in the Central African Republic (CAR). Concretely, it aims to increase information and awareness to access prevention and treatment services for COVID-19. The project is implemented in close collaboration with the national committee for the management of the COVID-19 crisis and is necessary because of disinformation and rumors that reduce the effectiveness of the COVID-19 control programs implemented by the Ministry of Health. By targeting populations particularly vulnerable to COVID-19, people with pre-existing diseases such as diabetics, tuberculosis patients and people living with HIV with a view to heightened awareness and referral to health services available, the project contributes to a targeted response to COVID-19 in CAR.

title.narrative: Promoting Peaceful Coexistence in the COVID-19 Response for Migrants, Refugees and Other Vulnerable Populations in Central America and the Caribbean

description.narrative: Implemented through a Multi-Partner Contribution Agreement with IOM and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), this project aims to promote integration and peaceful coexistence by improving the health response, community engagement and the protection of affected communities in Latin America and the Caribbean, particularly El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, and Haiti. The COVID-19 pandemic has had vast impacts on the socioeconomic well-being and health of the region's population, affecting the considerable number of vulnerable populations most including indigenous populations, stranded migrants, returnees, refugees, asylum seekers, internally displaced persons, and vulnerable host/transit community members. While each country faces distinct challenges, there is an overall need to support governments in their COVID-19 responses in order to ensure these populations are not left behind. Risk of conflict and insecurity is high because of the pandemic's wide-ranging effects on a region characterized by insecurity, violence, and limited institutional capacity. As borders remain partially or completely closed and health systems are overwhelmed, IOM and UNHCR have the operational capacity in the region and the institutional expertise to support governments in their efforts to mitigate conflict as a result of the pandemic.

For 12 months, IOM is carrying out activities under the first and third outcomes in target areas on the main corridor of the commercial exchange between the Central African Republic and Cameroun, where the population is exposed to local transmission of COVID-19. In line with its long-standing mandate and multi-sectoral expertise, IOM advocates for the adoption of sustainability-oriented reintegration policies that respond to the economic, social and psychosocial needs of returning migrants while also benefiting communities of origin and addressing structural challenges to reintegration.

title.narrative: Promoting Location-Specific Inclusion in Iraq

description.narrative: In order to promote the stabilization of conflict-affected communities and/or other communities with intensive needs based on conflict assessments previously conducted by IOM Iraq’s Community Stabilization Unit, IOM seeks to provide the Government of Iraq with support to address two of the country’s most pressing challenges of reintegration of families with a perceived affiliation to ISIL to return to and co-exist with their communities of origin and other conflict-affected communities (a secondary location of settlement), while also bolstering resilience to future waves of violent extremism within these communities; and the socio-economic reintegration of former combatants who have spontaneously disengaged and returned to their area of origin. In addition, IOM provides assistance to vulnerable communities in Iraq to sustain peace in the context of COVID-19 by addressing socio-economic impacts brought on by the pandemic.

title.narrative: Provision of Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) and Shelter-NFI Emergency Supplies for Flood Affected Populations in South Sudan

description.narrative: IOM, as the Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) and Shelter/Non-Food Items (S/NFI) Pipeline agency supports OCHA and the Clusters to provide frontline life-saving assistance within the immediate South Sudan flood response through provision and transportation of in-kind WASH and S/NFI supplies. With CERF funding, IOM’s Pipeline is procuring the core WASH and S/NFI items to replenish the supplies released in the form of flood survival items for affected people targeted by WASH and S/NFI Cluster. The project is in line with the CERF and WASH and S/NFI Clusters’ sector specific objectives as it prioritizes the most urgent and life-saving WASH static and mobile responses, as well as adequate shelter and appropriate NFI supplies for newly displaced or vulnerable populations as well as host communities who are unable to meet their basic WASH and emergency shelter and NFI needs as a result of the massive floods in the country. Following WHO’s declaration of COVID-19 as pandemic, and the establishment of the COVID-19 Taskforce in South Sudan, IOM Pipeline in coordination with both S/NFI and WASH Clusters, is scaling up activities to complement efforts on COVID-19 preparedness and response actions.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Lifesaving Emergency Assistance to Vulnerable Migrants Affected by Floods in Djibouti

description.narrative: Under this project IOM will identify vulnerable migrant households in need of assistance and through voucher system will target households with emergency non-food items (NFIs), including water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) items, and shelter repair kits. In addition, Djibouti has seen the rapid escalation of COVID-19 confirmed case in the past few weeks. The particular migration profile of the country, being the common migratory route from Ethiopia to Saudi Arabia for many travellers by land, and the closure of borders, put at risk a greater number of migrants transiting through Djibouti and unable to travel to their country of destination. Given the challenging situation that is anticipated, the Government of Djibouti has sought the support of IOM in providing lifesaving assistance to the migrants currently hosted in the government-led site of Masagara, and the migrants that will be gathered in Ali-Sabieh, in the form of provision of emergency shelter and NFIs in coordination with the other UN-agencies involved.

description.narrative: As displaced communities in Cabo Delgado and Nampula remain vulnerable to natural disasters and conflict, IOM's intervention directly contributes to increase the preparedness future disasters through pre-positioning of non-food item (NFI) stock and strengthening of the assessment capacity for natural disaster risk analysis and data made available through the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) in Cabo Delgado. In light of the global COVID-19 pandemic, and the large-scale migratory in-flow of Mozambicans workers returning from South Africa, Zimbabwe, and other neighbouring countries, as a result of lock-downs or other restrictive policies, a crisis modifier will enable IOM to quickly activate and deploy resources at key border crossing points, return communities and, to the extent possible, in internal displaced person's settlement in central areas of the country, in efforts to prevent and mitigate associated risks of communal transmission.

description.narrative: Through this project, IOM is providing humanitarian assistance to conflict affected households in Greater Upper Nile, vulnerable internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Protection of Civilians (PoC) sites and collective settlements, as well as communities outside of camp settings suffering shocks in South Sudan. In particular, IOM is providing mental health and psychosocial support, protection, water, sanitation and hygiene and shelter (WASH) and non-food Items assistance, as well as camp coordination and camp management and primary health-care services. In addition, in order to respond to COVID-19, IOM is providing critical WASH items, constructing hand washing infrastructure and conducting risk communication activities.

title.narrative: Multisectoral Humanitarian Assistance for Displaced and Mobile Populations in Sudan

description.narrative: The aim of this project is to contribute towards efforts to address urgent humanitarian needs through a multi-sectoral approach focused on providing integrated support to displaced and vulnerable crisis-affected populations. To achieve this aim, the project will focus on three inter-related outcomes centered on i) collecting and sharing with partners’ up-to-date information needed to respond effectively to humanitarian needs; ii) providing emergency shelter and non-food items to vulnerable populations; and, iii) mitigating potential causes of tension and conflict (resource-driven and inter-community) by promoting peaceful co-existence through improved access to basic services and livelihood opportunities. As the recent outbreak of COVID-19 is further exacerbating an already stretched health system and worsening an already dire economic situation, the project will include mainstreamed and dedicated activities to respond to the COVID-19 outbreak in particular with regards to health and livelihoods but also water, sanitation and hygiene activities.

title.narrative: Provision of Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Services Targeting Displaced Populations Hosted in Camp and Camp-like Settings and Hosting Communities in North-East Nigeria

description.narrative: In response to the needs that have been identified by the water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) Sector and in line with the Nigeria Humanitarian Fund Allocation Strategy, this project will support the continuation and scaling-up of WASH assistance in camp and camp-like setting and in hosting communities. The project will address access to safe water through the care and maintenance of existing boreholes, improved sanitation through the construction and maintenance of shower and latrine blocks with handwashing stations, enhanced cholera preparedness and response and overall improved hygiene through increased awareness on hygiene, COVID-19 and cholera prevention through targeted messaging, as well as solid waste management. Cholera messaging will be extended to host communities, who will benefit indirectly from the other forms of assistance as well. To ensure a timely and holistic response to the multi-sectoral needs of displaced populations in camps and camp-like settings, the activities will be implemented in conjunction with other components of IOM’s emergency response for an integral response.

title.narrative: IOM Ethiopia Funding Requirement for the COVID-19 Preparedness and Response

description.narrative: COVID-19 pandemic continues to present unprecedented impacts on Ethiopian society. Ethiopia's Planning and Development Commission (PDC), the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the UN all expect COVID-19 to pose major adverse impacts on the economy as well as on household welfare and human dignity due to low economic growth, close of businesses, and reduced productivity in key sectors such as agriculture and services. The pandemic has also heightened existing vulnerabilities among highly vulnerable groups. Ethiopian migrants who end up stranded in countries from in the Horn of Africa and the Gulf. The proposed project aims to contribute to a well-coordinated, informed, and timely response to COVID-19 in Gambella and Tigray Regional States. For this, IOM is: 1) Enhancing the capacity of Humera and Pagak points of entry (POE) in the areas of surveillance, Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) and risk communication; 2) Empowering individuals and communities to adopt preventative and health seeking behaviours necessary for reducing the spread of the coronavirus; and 3) improving access to non-food items (NFIs) and essential health and protection services for targeted returnees, refugees, and asylum seekers.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Improving Life-Saving Assistance and Health Care Services to Migrants and Refugees from Venezuela in Brazil

description.narrative: In March 2020, in view of the COVID-19 global pandemic, Brazil has declared a national emergency, ordered the closure of its national borders and imposed several restrictions on economic activities and population mobility. The rapid spread of the disease and its immediate socioeconomic consequences have created new challenges to all vulnerable populations in Brazil and severely impacted the situation of Venezuelan migrants and refugees living in the country. The overall objective of this project is to improve life-saving emergency assistance to Venezuelan migrants and refugees in the state of Roraima. In the context of the pandemic and in line with the regional Refugees and Migrants Response Plan (RMRP) 2021, the proposed intervention focuses on providing food and non-food item assistance and improving health care services to migrants and refugees.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Strengthening the Disaster Response and Preparedness Capacity in Niger through the Construction of a Multi-purpose Evacuation Site

description.narrative: Since 2011, the Séno site located in the suburbs of Niamey has been designated by the Government of Niger as a temporary emergency evacuation site for flood victims. More recently, in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, it is being used to accommodate the Nigerien returnees for their quarantine. However, due to the rainy season and the sandstorms, many of the emergency shelters have been damaged and require continuous reparations. Also, the site is facing many electricity as well as water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) related challenges due to poor drainage. Floods represent a recurrent phenomenon in Niamey and other parts of Niger, which require dedicated and adequate solutions for systematic evacuation options. In addition, the COVID-19 pandemic triggered heavy operational challenges to IOM’s assisted voluntary return assistance to stranded migrants. Temporary shelter solutions for returning migrants from Niger to their countries of origin are necessary, while ensuring adherence to the required public health measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Capitalizing on the Séno site experience described above, there is an urgent need to build a multi-purpose site that would meet the quarantine and isolation minimum standards in terms of site management, site design and first aid needs.

title.narrative: Emergency Grant Aid for People Affected by the Military Engagement in Tigray Region, Ethiopia

description.narrative: The conflict in Tigray region of Ethiopia, coupled with pre-existing humanitarian needs and the COVID-19 pandemic context in northern Ethiopia, has created a concerning, volatile humanitarian situation, as numerous civilians have been displaced within Tigray, into other Ethiopian Regional States, and into neighbouring states of Sudan. The project aims to contribute to the improvement of the physical and mental wellbeing, as well as living conditions for crisis-affected populations in Northern Ethiopia through the provision of essential health and mental health and psychosocial support, as well as shelter repair assistance. The intervention targets internally displaced persons (IDPs), host communities, and returnee IDPs affected by the Northern Ethiopian Crisis in Tigray and Amhara regions.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Provision of Shelter and Settlements Assistance for Populations Affected by the Northern Ethiopian Crisis

description.narrative: In November 2020, tensions between the national and regional governments developed into widespread conflict in the Tigray Region of Ethiopia. The conflict has driven large-scale displacement, with populations fleeing to areas not directly under attack within the Tigray region, and to neighbouring Afar and Amhara Regions, and Sudan. The security situation in Tigray Region remains unstable, particularly in rural areas to which large numbers of people have fled, and access constraints due to persisting insecurity continue to challenge the urgent scale up of humanitarian assistance. This conflict, coupled with pre-existing humanitarian needs and against the backdrop of the COVID-19 pandemic in northern Ethiopia, has created a dire humanitarian situation, as numerous civilians have been displaced within Tigray, into other Ethiopian Regional States, and into neighbouring states such as Sudan. Through this project, IOM is contributing to the improvement of living conditions and the well-being of crisis-affected populations in Northern Ethiopia through Shelter and Settlements interventions.

title.narrative: Supporting Vulnerable Refugees and Local Communities in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh, through Improved Access to Health, Protection, and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Services

description.narrative: Over three and a half years have passed since the forced displacement of Rohingya men, women, boys and girls from Myanmar into Bangladesh. Early leadership exercised by the Government of Bangladesh, with the support of the international community, worked to mitigate and manage the ensuing humanitarian crisis in the southern district of Cox’s Bazar. Despite resilience and resolve shown by the refugee community, there exists as of yet no viable solution to the crisis until a safe and voluntary return to Rakhine state is guaranteed. The Rohingya who sought refuge in Cox’s Bazar, continue to face formidable challenges and require Protection and other life-saving humanitarian assistance, with COVID-19 and monsoon season in 2020 further exacerbating needs. This project contributes to the reduction of morbidity and mortality among refuges and host community by improving equitable access to and utilization of quality life-saving and comprehensive primary and secondary health services for all crisis-affected populations. It reduces protection threats and vulnerabilities and strengthens protection services to meet the protection needs of refugees and host community; and upholds the safety and dignity of Rohingya refugees through improved comprehensive water, sanitation and hygiene infrastructure and services.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Providing Life-Saving Assistance to Crisis-Affected Populations in Sudan to Reduce Their Vulnerability, Restore a Minimum Sense of Dignity, Mitigate Health Risks, and Improve Living Conditions

description.narrative: Intercommunal conflict and violence erupted on 15 January 2021 between Arab and Massalit tribes, in El Geneina town and across West Darfur, Sudan. The humanitarian needs and vulnerabilities in West Darfur are further compounded by the COVID-19 pandemic, which places additional strain on limited resources and basic services, reduces livelihoods, and creates significant economic and health implications. In this project, IOM ensures that displaced populations affected by conflict and violence are provided with emergency shelter and non-food items, as well as protection services including mental health and psychosocial support, legal assistance and guidance on civil documentation for affected populations.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Rohingya Response and National Resilience Programme (RRNRP)

description.narrative: 2021 marks the fourth year since the massive displacement of Rohingya refugees from Myanmar into Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh. While the Government of Bangladesh and international community have maintained the provision of immediate lifesaving assistance, the needs are immense and complex challenges continue to emerge and reshape the nature of the response. The humanitarian community swiftly shifted priorities in 2020 to respond to the impact of COVID-19 on the Rohingya and host communities. With the scale up of COVID-19 interventions, other humanitarian services reduced. Studies revealed a decrease in shelter maintenance and livelihoods, and deterioration in the protection environment, and deepen the impact of the crisis on host communities with price increases and strained livelihoods. Alongside these challenges, monsoon and cyclone preparedness and response will remain at the forefront of the response in 2021 for the humanitarian communities in Cox’s Bazar. Through this project, IOM is supporting programme efforts through protection, shelter, health, water, sanitation and hygiene, site management and site development.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Multi-Sectoral Support to Communities Affected by Conflict and Natural Hazards

description.narrative: Since the collapse of the Somali central government in 1991, Somalia has suffered a highly complex protracted conflict characterized by changing political dynamics and power shifts. Although there have been improvements to the peace and security situation in Somalia since the formation of the Federal Government of Somalia in 2012, the overall situation remains fragile with Al-Shabab a major obstacle to peace and security. Forced displacement remains an ongoing a reality for people living in Somalia due to armed conflict, environmental hardships due to climate change, combined with inadequate resource distribution that is often exacerbated by clan based, ideological differences and land and natural resources competition. The COVID-19 pandemic has added yet another hazard that people in Somalia face. While it has now been over a year since the first case was detected in Somalia and efforts have been made to mitigate the risk, the situation is always evolving. With the main objective to ensure dignified, safe and secure living conditions and basic services for vulnerable populations affected by conflict and disasters in Somalia, IOM proposes an integrated camp coordination and camp management, Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) and shelter and non-food item emergency support.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Provision of Integrated Protection and Life-Saving Health Services to Migrants and IDPs in Yemen

description.narrative: Migration through Yemen has become a riskier process over the past 2-3 years and COVID-19 has exacerbated or accelerated certain trends. Migrants are amongst the most marginalized, excluded and vulnerable groups of people in need in Yemen. The on-going crisis and conflict, combined with the hardening attitudes of authorities against migrants, has increased their exposure to abuse and violence. As Yemen’s humanitarian situation worsens, critical indicators such as access to health care, water and sanitation, food insecurity and malnutrition are worsening, and civilians are becoming increasingly exposed to conflict. This action aims to build on IOM and partners' current migrant assistance and response capacity that meets the most critical needs of migrants traveling through Yemen. The action contributes to this goal through the continued employment of an integrated health and protection approach that prioritizes the most vulnerable migrants in Yemen at disembarkation points, along transit routes and hubs, and in locations where migrants are stranded or trapped as a result of conflict, crisis barriers and/or the impact of COVID-19 border closures. IOM and partners are providing migrants with access to health assistance, information on safe migration, individualized protection support and immediate short-term and emergency support that addresses demonstrated needs.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Responding to Humanitarian Needs of Palestinian Refugees, Labour Migrants and Third Country Nationals Stranded in Gaza, Egypt

description.narrative: Since 10 May 2021, increased military and armed hostilities in Gaza Strip resulted in mounting casualties. According to the Palestinian Ministry of Health, between 10 and 17 May, 220 Palestinians were killed and 6,039 injured in the Palestinian Territories. Additionally, over 34,000 people have been displaced. Following the ceasefire on 21 May 2021, most of the displaced individuals have returned to their homes. However, about 1,000 people whose homes were destroyed or severely damaged still remain in need for urgent humanitarian assistance in Gaza. There is concern about the transmission of COVID-19 between vulnerable people who huddled in crowded shelters and the health-care system’s inability to cope. In coordination with the Government of Egypt and the Egyptian Red Crescent (ERC), IOM is providing life-saving humanitarian and movement assistance to displaced Palestinian populations and affected labour and stranded migrants in a dignified and safe manner and in line with international humanitarian law.

title.narrative: Enhancing the Humane Management of Mixed Migration Flows in Zimbabwe through the Provision of Life-Saving Assistance and Protection of Migrants’ Dignity and Rights, in Order to Build Resilience and Strengthen Social Cohesion.

description.narrative: The unpredictable and critical nature of Zimbabwe has reinforced the need for IOM to continue conducting data collection through Protection information management tools as the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) to provide information on the location and multisectoral needs of the affected population particularly returnees to the humanitarian partners for a more targeted response, since most of them remain dependent on humanitarian assistance. The focus of this intervention is mainly at Border level and will be achieved by continuing the provision of services for the main points of entry (POEs) of the country (Beitbridge, Plumtree and Chirundu), while extending services to a key POE (Forbes). In addition, the action proposes to continue strengthening the capacity of Government to properly manage migration flows, while improving the existing coordination mechanisms and providing the resources required to guarantee the protection of vulnerable migrants, in terms of the life-threatening challenges related to the spread of COVID-19 and tackling vulnerabilities by challenging discrimination and inequalities.
